Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to remain vital, the American economy must compete globally, attract investment, and create jobs. This project will address the shortage of qualified STEM technicians and professionals in the nation's workforce by increasing the number of well prepared graduates with an Associate of Science degree with a focus on biology, chemistry, or mathematics or an Associate of Applied Science in engineering from Asheville-Buncombe Technical Community College (A-B Tech). The project will amass multiple stakeholders including faculty members and collaborators from public schools, 4-year institutions, and industry to serve a minimum of 134 academically talented and financially needy students.

The primary goal of the project is to bolster student persistence and achievement through support services (co-advising, case management, tutoring, mentoring, and internships) and academic enrichment activities (seminars, service learning, college tours, and industry visits). A secondary goal is to develop a viable and reproducible model for joint high school, community college, and university pathway efforts to address an increasing labor shortage of well prepared STEM technicians and professionals. Formative evaluation will focus on student participation in student support services and engagement in enrichment activities (surveys and focus groups). Summative data collection will focus on student persistence and completion information (mid-term and final grades, re-enrollment, and goal completion). Dissemination of results will be achieved through presentations at the NC Community College Student Development Personnel Association and NC Community College System Office State-wide conferences and through the institution's AB-Tech Education Journal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ignite Inspiration and Innovation (I3) NSF S-STEM Outcomes Report

Ignite Inspiration and Innovation (I3) increased the retention, completion and success rates of STEM students at Asheville-Buncombe Technical Community College (A-B Tech). Participants received enhanced mentoring, advising, tutoring, enrichment activities and financial support. During the five-year project, a total of 156 scholarships were awarded to 73 unduplicated students; $514,000 in scholarships were disbursed.

Participants had extremely high retention and graduation rates.  Ninety-two percent (92%) of I3 students graduated with a STEM-related Associate of Science (AS), Associate of Engineering (AE) or Associate of Applied Science Engineering Technology (AAS) degree, transferred to a four-year institution or retained eligibility for the program (full-time status, 3.2 or higher GPA, unmet financial need and progress towards a STEM degree). 

The cohort showed significantly higher rates of academic success than their peers. Participants had a 22% higher rate of achieving "A" or "B" grades in their courses; I3 students completed 92% of their courses with an "A" or "B" grade, as opposed to 70% of their peers. 

In addition to quantitative measures of success, participants provided qualitative feedback. Participants were surveyed at the end of each semester. Many said that without this program, they would not have finished their degree. Participants reported the program had a significant impact on keeping them enrolled and enabled them to achieve academic success. Several participants were first generation college students and the first in their families to graduate.

Mentoring and advising were important aspects of the program.  Mentoring sessions encouraged students to stay on track towards earning their degrees, allowed students to ask questions and receive feedback regarding their progress, and allowed quick intervention in situations where academic success was threatened.

One-on-one tutoring was provided at no cost to students and was an important factor in student success. Tutoring sessions allowed students to receive targeted support with a dedicated tutor who was familiar with their coursework and able to tailor the sessions to meet the needs of each student.

Enrichment opportunities included a "STEM Friday" lecture series and active-learning workshops. The seminars and workshops were specifically prepared for the I3 participants, allowing these academically gifted students to explore STEM-related topics in-depth. The Scientific Literacy workshop developed students' critical thinking skills, supporting success in academic and workplace settings. EXCEL workshops taught students computer skills necessary for both college and workplace environments. Mock interviews allowed students to polish speaking skills and prepare for college and workplace interviews.

Internships, service learning and shadowing activities were offered. These opportunities allowed students to learn about local companies and experience STEM-related workplace environments. Upon completion of their degrees, several students obtained full-time employment at companies where they had interned. Participants also toured four-year colleges and met with transfer advisors and former I3 participants. This will result in students making informed transfer decisions increase their success at four-year schools.

Volunteerism and service-learning provided opportunities for students to give back to the community and the environment. Students participated in local STEM outreach activities ranging from water testing to astronomy and judging robotics competitions.

I3 students received exceptional recognition for their academic success. Participants were named as A-B Tech's Outstanding Student of the Year in the AS and AE programs, received academic excellence awards in math, chemistry, biology and engineering technology, and were named to the President's and Dean's lists for academic success. Participants received highly competitive academic awards and honors from outside organizations, and many received full or partial scholarships upon transfer to four-year institutions.

In addition to participating in I3, a female student attended the NASA Community College Aerospace Scholars Onsite Experience at Kennedy Space Center, was awarded the prestigious Jack Kent Cooke Foundation Undergraduate Transfer Scholarship, completed her AS degree with a perfect 4.0 GPA, and transferred to the UNC-Asheville/NC State University joint degree program in Mechatronics engineering.

Other participants were a NASA Student Ambassador, NASA Community College Aerospace Scholars and NASA L'SPACE Virtual Academy attendees. Students also received NC Space Grant Scholarships and participated in the NC Space Grant for Undergraduate Research project.

One participant's robotics team won the District and Regional Engineering Inspiration Award in the FIRST Robotic Competition and competed on the national level in Houston. He was selected to go to NASA's Langley Research Center to participate in the NASA Community College Aerospace Scholars onsite experience, and is now enrolled in the UNC-Asheville/NC State University joint engineering program.

Another participant spent four days working with a team to design and program a rover to retrieve samples through a NASA-sponsored program. "We had to do it all autonomously and it didn't always work. The second day, we re-programmed and we won the competition," he said. He will transfer to UNC-A/NC State for a Mechatronics degree.

Each I3 student success story is a life changed and a contribution to the future of STEM.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2020
Modified by: Susan Schwarz
